text:
OK. Hi, everyone, and welcome to
the 2025 HBS Entrepreneurship

Summit. Woo! [CHEERS, APPLAUSE] We're super excited
to have you here

today, especially
because this is our re-inaugural
Entrepreneurship Summit.

There hasn't been an event like
this at HBS since pre-COVID. So we're really excited to
have this relaunch again

and have you guys all here. So if you haven't taken
a seat yet, take a seat. Settle in.

We're super excited for
a full day of programming here with you today.

Special shoutout to our co-heads
of Summit, Lindsay and Ankita. You'll meet them in a second.

Woo! We would not be here
without them today. I know it's been months of work.

Their leadership and vision
is why we're all here today. So we're super excited
to kick things off.

And so the HBS E club-- we're one of the
largest student clubs

here on campus, which
is a great testament to the entrepreneurial
spirit here at HBS.

I'm Jing. I'm one of the
presidents of E club. And I'm here with
Hunter, my co-president.

And so we were excited to kick
things back off here and bring everyone together from both
HBS, RCs, ECs, alums, as well

as community leaders. So we have a lot of
student representation from all across the Boston area.

We have people flying in
from all across the nation, so excited to have
everyone come here today.

Hopefully, you'll
meet a new friend, a connection, a potential
entrepreneurial venture.

And so with that,
I'm going to turn it to Hunter here to kick things
off for our first keynote.

[APPLAUSE] Awesome. Thank you, Jing. Again, I'm so grateful
to Lindsay and Ankita

for all they've done. Planning a full-day conference
with no roadmap is no easy feat, and they've done it with aplomb.

And we hope and
expect this to be the foundation
and the groundwork for a number of great summits
and conferences in the years

to come. To me falls the pleasure of
introducing our first keynote. First, our moderator
is Patrick Chung.

He's the managing
GP of Xfund, which is the VC fund that was founded
in partnership with the Harvard Engineering School.

He was formerly
a partner at NEA. And he's a rare
triple Harvard alum, holding not only
an MBA from HBS,

is Aravind Srinivas,
the CEO of Perplexity. Aravind was born
in Chennai, India.

He holds a bachelor's
and master's in electrical engineering
from IIT Madras, as well as a PhD in computer
science from UC Berkeley.

And Perplexity, in
case you've been living under a rock for
the last few years, is a AI-powered, conversational
search engine that's

been taking the world by storm. Aravind co-founded
Perplexity in 2022. And in the few short
years since, Perplexity

has achieved over 600 million
monthly queries and a $9 billion valuation, with investments
from the likes of Jeff Bezos

and Nvidia. And yes, if you are wondering,
I did use Perplexity to help write this intro.

Aravind, who's going to
be on stage in one minute, a heartfelt thank
you from all of us for flying across the
country to be with us.

I know we're all really excited
to hear the insights you have to share from the trenches
of company building

in the gen-AI world. Please welcome me in
joining Patrick and Aravind. [APPLAUSE]

Aravind, thank you
so much for flying all the way across the
country to be with us. Thank you for having me here.

It's actually my
first time at Harvard, so very excited to be here. So we are all intensely
interested about Perplexity,

about AI, about the future. But I wanted to back
up a bit and just talk about your origin
story, and then we'll

talk about Perplexity, and then
we'll talk about the future. So unlike many, many founders,
you are actually an academic.

We sit here at Harvard, one
of the great universities of the world, whose mission is
to seek truth, create knowledge.

Can you just trace your history
from undergrad through academia? Yeah.

I mean, firstly,
the cultural roots for me was to always seek
knowledge even more than wealth.

That's how we grew up
back in Chennai, in India. And even now, I would say my
parents are even more proud

of my PhD than Perplexity.  They still use Google
quite a lot, so--

Oh, no. So that tells you what
they truly care about.

And so a lot of people kind
think academia and business

are like two separate things. There's a lot of things
you can learn from academia

and apply it in business. And so in IIT, I did my
electrical engineering degree,

which now I'm feeling
good about it. But back then, I
always felt like, oh, I

should be in computer science. Like, all the cool kids
are in computer science.

So I need to also get into
all these coding competitions. And I tried my hand
at competitive coding.

I wasn't good at it. Johnny is my co-founder. He's also here. He was actually world
number one at IOI.

And I think he represented
Harvard also at ICPC. So there were a lot of
better people even back then.

So I never made it to
the ICPC world final. So I-- Is that your biggest regret?

Well, not anymore, like,
you know, but definitely wish I was good at it.

I tried my hand at a
machine learning contest with literally
zero understanding

of what machine
learning even means, just trying different algorithms
from the scikit-learn library.

And I essentially brute force
my way into winning the contest.

But that-- Was it a college contest? Yeah, it was within the college,
just open to all the students.

And I think Yahoo probably
sponsored that event. And I got-- but the money
wasn't the important part of it.

It's mostly like it was fun to
actually try something new where there were no guarantees
of correctness.

You just had to try
a bunch of things. What was the contest? I mean, it has
echoes of what you're going to be doing for
us this afternoon,

which is a pitch competition
that you will judge. Yeah, correct. Contest was like they
had a bunch of photos

and wanted to classify,
but they wouldn't actually give you the photos. They would give you a bunch of
numbers that they featurized.

And you had to predict
on an unseen test set. And no deep learning
or neural nets back

then, just simple algorithms. And that's how I
got started in ML.

Wow. And I did an internship. And they asked me to
build a recommender system

for health care website. Did you win the contest? Yeah, I did win the contest. OK, so you were an electrical
engineering undergrad.

You entered a machine
learning undergrad contest. You won it. And what did that say to you?

I majored in the wrong thing? Actually, electrical
engineering is very easy

to onboard into ML, even
easier than computer science, because I was already familiar
with concepts like convolutions

and signal processing, all these
low-pass, high-pass filters.

And so all the
Python programming in NumPy, all this stuff
came pretty intuitively.

Whereas for computer
science friends of mine, they were more focused
on competitive coding.

They would always write for
loops for every single thing. That's not the
best way to do ML.

So I think that
definitely helped me a lot to get started even sooner.

So I don't regret the whole
electrical engineering beginnings of it.
And so I got my internship. I learned more. Where were you an intern?

I was just doing an internship
in India at a startup. I finished it pretty fast, like
building a recommender system.

That's when someone told me,
hey, look, there's all this-- linear algebra is cool, but you
got to go study neural nets.

It doesn't work, but you
still got to go study it. And so that's how
I started watching

all these online lectures,
Andrew Ng's lectures on YouTube. And then someone told me,
you know, Andrew Ng is cool,

but there's a British guy
who speaks really slowly, so watch it at 1.5x.

His lectures are even better. That was Geoffrey
Hinton's lectures. And so that's how I
learned all my basics,

and then did my
research, and luckily got an internship with Yoshua
Bengio, one of the Turing Award

winners. He wrote me a letter. And that's how I got into
grad school at Berkeley.

And yeah, so that was
my start from undergrad to coming to the US.

Once I got in here, I was
lucky to get internships at OpenAI and DeepMind.

That completely humbled me
a lot because I actually thought I was good. And then people around
me were way more intense,

hard working, way
better at actually not just coming
up with new ideas, but implementing them
and getting them working,

or writing all the
code to scrape data sets, everything end to end. That was happening here.

So that taught me
a lot and pushed me more towards entrepreneurship,
not just coming up

with new ideas. But it's very essential
that you actually show them working in practice
on a practical data set.

Was that the-- what was the
kernel that-- because you were on this academic track. You actually completed
your PhD at Berkeley.

Yeah. And so were the internships
the one that said, OK-- that kind of dislodged
you from that default path?

Yeah, so completion-- yeah. I know what you're
trying to say. Like, being a dropout is
cooler than completing the PhD.

No, I'm not saying that. I'm not saying-- just for the
record, I'm not saying that. But let me see.

I think by the time-- my
advisor was pretty open minded.

So I went and told
him, look, I know I came here to do a PhD
in reinforcement learning, but basically what happened was
I got an internship at OpenAI,

and I had some five
or six very fancy reinforcement learning ideas.

And Ilya Sutskever, the
former chief scientist there, literally told me
all the ideas suck.

He told it to my face
exactly like this. And obviously, I was
very upset with that.

Nobody usually
tells it this way, so maybe he's actually right. And then he took me to a board
and just drew two circles--

one big circle and inside
it a smaller circle. And so the big
circle is generative unsupervised learning.

And the smaller circle is
reinforcement learning. And you don't need anything new.

You just need to
do this in sequence and throw a lot of
compute at it and train on all of the internet.

And then you'll build
a general intelligence. So don't work on all your ideas.

Wait, really? Like, nobody had any
clue at the time, but he just saw the future. And that ended up being right.

That's essentially the
recipe for ChatGPT. But I at least went back to
my advisor and said, hey,

there's this new thing called
generative unsupervised learning. Let's go and study it. And then we taught a
class at Berkeley on that.

And I learned that myself. And I did more internships to
write more papers on that topic.
And I combined the two together. That ended up being my thesis. So that was very essential.

So when I got more
into critical thinking, I started looking
at startups that
can potentially be new in AI. Well, why-- just to pause there. Why look at startups?

Why wouldn't you have just
stated a big tech company? You were at Google. You were at DeepMind. You were at OpenAI.

What was the kernel
of it that made you decide, I'm going to start
my own thing instead keep on with one of these
big tech companies?

So I did my PhD at
Berkeley, so I'm pretty close to Silicon Valley.

I'm definitely not
like making it up. Like, I really
thought that TV show

Silicon Valley was pretty cool. Oh, no. Everybody was
watching it around me.

And then I thought
it was very funny. But then someone
actually told me, hey, look, I know you're making jokes
about the show all the time,

but realize that some people
might take it personally because it's
actually pretty true.

It's not just like
a humorous show. Like, a lot of people were
very depressed watching it

because it reflects Silicon
Valley in almost a brutal way. But I think the whole idea of
starting something from scratch

and getting it in the hands
of users was very attractive. And the particular idea in
that TV show that was explored

was around lossless compression,
which is very directly tied to generative AI
because if you--

they also talk a lot about
how you can use neural nets to do it. So that was actually
the idea I really

wanted to start up first on,
like lossless compression with generative models, except
nobody wanted to do it with me.

And then COVID happened. So I just-- and Ilya told me to
come to OpenAI and work there.

And it wasn't very clear where
AI was clearly heading to, like a product phase.

It was still pretty
research-oriented. But then products
like GitHub Copilot started spinning out from
OpenAI and Microsoft.

And it was like the first real
time that I could use it myself. Like, I knew AI was already
being applied in industry,

like Facebook's
recommender systems, or Google Search was using
all this link ranking.

They were all using
a lot of neural nets, but you couldn't
viscerally feel it. I think you started feeling it
more when you used it yourself.

And GitHub Copilot was
this AI that would just autocomplete your code
when you're writing code

in your editor right there. So when you feel the AI--
there's this whole phrase "feel

the AGI" or "feel the AI--" I
think you start to realize, OK, now is the moment to
try to start a company.

And you kind of have to
be at the right place at the right time. We were very lucky
to be that, where

AI was just beginning to work. It was not fully working yet
that it would be too late. And so if we assemble a
really great group of people

and gather a little
bit of funding and get the right seed
idea, we could potentially

build a product and benefit
from all the advances that happen in AI and all
the new investments that are going to come in.

So that's kind of how Perplexity
was started in August of 2022. Wow, cool.

Just as a little
aside, Mike Judge, who was the producer
of Silicon Valley, was looking for advisors.

And I happened to be an
advisor on season one-- Oh, cool. --of that show. So that's a little--

Are you in the show? No. No. But he wanted-- he just wanted
Silicon Valley gossip in order

to satirize. And I was the apparently
willing provider. But OK, so you
started this company.

And how did you find
your co-founders? How did you find
your first investors?

And it'd be interesting
to-- as we transition from your academic background
to the startup, what

parts of your
academic upbringing influenced the company
that you built today?

So first of all, Denis Yarats-- he's the co-founder
and CTO of Perplexity--

I knew him at least
for a year or more before we started Perplexity.

From school? Yeah. He didn't go to Berkeley,
but he went to NYU.

And he wrote the same
paper as me one day apart. But who published first?
Technically, he did. OK. Yeah. OK. Actually, it was-- He became a very good hire then?

In the sense-- like, he
actually gave us a heads up saying he's publishing
it because he had heard we were working on the same thing.

So we actually rushed
and pulled an all-nighter and got our paper
out the next day. So that's how we got acquainted.

And then he became a visiting
student in my lab remotely because of COVID.

And so we used to discuss
a lot of ideas back then. And he knew Johnny, who
overlapped with him at Quora

back when humans used to
answer people's questions. Now AIs do that. So Quora was a platform
where other people would

come and answer your questions. And then it was-- assembled a great group of
competitive programmers.

And so they overlapped
with each other there and worked on
this thing called Quora Digest, which
automatically picks

the questions that are
most relevant to you and sends it as an email,
which I still get these days.

And sometimes it's
pretty useful even now.

So Denis was like, oh,
Johnny's potentially leaving his job at
Tower and looking

for something to do in AI. So maybe we should talk. Well, it's one thing to
identify great people, but how did you wrest
them from their fancy jobs

and from their
academic trajectories? In this case, we lucked out. He was actually
looking to leave. OK.

So it was more
like convincing him that we would be
the right next step. Actually, he took
a pretty bold bet because we had nothing, right?

This is Johnny or Denis or both? So Denis decided to leave Meta. He felt like he had an
urge to do a startup

at some point in his life. But once Denis signed up, he
said, OK, let's convince Johnny. It's like a snowball?

Yeah, exactly. For Johnny, I think he
was deciding between us and some other startup.

And we had nothing. So I think he just
took a bold bet. Like, we were
initially were working

on using AI to answer
questions about data sets. Like, if you had your
employees' salary database,

and you wanted to ask
how many people earn more than a certain amount-- all this text SQL--

that's basically what
we were working on. We had no idea if it had any
market impact or business model.

In fact, I still don't think
it does-- that particular idea. But the most
important realization is that in a startup, when you
have an initial group of people,

the number one thing to do is
just iterate and do something. I've seen many founders
spend at least six months

to a year in the idea maze
going around and around and not getting anywhere and
not knowing what it takes

to actually ship something,
get it in the hands of people, see them use it, learn
from that, and then go

and update your hypothesis
about the world. Right. That's the right way to do
it, at least in software.

And so that really helped us. Like, we got a lot of dopamine
from watching others use it.

And that was also
how we raised funding from a good set
of seed investors,

where we would
just show the demo. Like, people would
ask for a deck. I would just say, I don't
know how to make decks.

I still don't know
how to make decks. I haven't made a deck
in ages, actually. Only one deck I made was
for our series A funding.

That was NEA's round, which I
don't think the deck was great, but I somehow convinced them.

Clearly, it was good enough. But after that, I
never made a deck. It was all like, let me
just do a demo for you

and tell you what
we want to get to. And that worked really
well for our seed round.

And especially what happened
is we would scrape Twitter back

when it was available in the
form of an API and pre-Elon Musk

CEO days. Now we would put that
into a bunch of tables and let people ask any
questions about Twitter.

So when the search--
existing search on Twitter never really worked. And suddenly you got
something that worked. People really got the idea that,
oh, large-language models are

really going to change search. It doesn't matter how exactly,
but it's really going to happen. So that's how we attracted
great seed investors--

Elad Gil, Nat Friedman,
Andrej Karpathy, Yann LeCun, Jeff Dean also.

So a lot of people invested. And that helped
us go and recruit some really good engineers,
founding engineers, who--

even if they didn't trust
me as a founder or a CEO to figure out things,
they trusted the fact

that, OK, a great
group of people are putting money into this. And the co-founders are very
technical and great engineers,

so wow, I probably
won't get an opportunity to work in a team
like this again.

So they came in. And somehow we
iterated, iterated, and launched the core idea
that, OK, search itself--

like the fundamental software,
the king of all software, the one that's used for
the most in the world, surface area and usage-wise--

can be changed, where if people
actually wanted to evolve search from typing in keywords
to typing in questions

or asking questions
via voice, and you just get an instant
answer, and you want to trust what the
answer of the AI

is whether true or
not through sources-- Which, again,
comes from academia because the first
thing you're taught

when you write a paper is, don't
just write whatever you want. Like, make sure you have a
peer-reviewed citation to it.

So we just applied that concept
in the context of an LLM and got it to work over
a weekend hack project.

A weekend? Yeah, yeah. I mean, by the way,
a lot of the intro was already built for
doing this in a weekend.

It's not like we literally
started from no code to launching it.

But we could quickly iterate,
had a Discord server and Slack bots, tried it ourselves,
saw our friends using it.

And that ended up
becoming Perplexity. So I've heard you say many
times that Perplexity is not

competitive with Google. And I wonder if you could
just help us explain that.

It feels like if I want
the answer to a question, they're substitutions.

Yeah. So can you explain
why you don't think you're competitive with Google? So I think it's not competitive
with Google in the sense

that it's not going to take away
the core Google Search behavior.

By the way, most of-- at least
one to two billion searches a day are just one or
two words right now.

Yeah. People just literally
typing in-- you go to trends.google.com,
and you scroll down.

Instead of rising,
you click the top. Most of the times, it's just
Reddit, Reddit, Instagram,

YouTube, Twitter-- these one-word destinations. And people just type that
on their Chrome search bar.

And it goes to the first link. And then they go there. But that's pretty
magical, isn't it, because Google's actually
reading your mind.

You have a query. Yeah. You're typing one or two words. And Google's
proposition to you is,

we are going to be able to read
your mind from those one or two words and give you exactly what
you want in the first page.

Yeah. That's the user intent,
like really recognizing, oh, the user wants like just
the quick information.

So we're not necessarily
going to compete there. I mean, potentially, if
we own the front end,

then all those searches
would go to us. But we're not-- there's
nothing to improve there in terms of the experience
because Google's already

doing a good job. But what they are not good
at is answering questions. Like, if you really
wanted to know,

OK, I'm actually going
to Harvard today, and it looks like it might rain. What is the best
thing for me to wear?

You're going to
get a lot of links, but you're not going to get a
synthesis of the information

presented in each
of them to give you a targeted answer
to that question. Instead, what you would
do before Perplexity was

you would type in the weather. And then you would
think about what to do. And then you would type in
something else related to,

what is the best thing to
wear for rainy weather? You would read that. And then you would be doing
all this cognitive work.

Now the AI is doing it for you. And so it's a much
more intuitive way-- Are you actually comparing
yourself to Google 1.0,

Yeah, I know what
you're talking about. The AI overview or the AI
mode doesn't always work.

It sometimes hallucinates,
like the famous cheese sticking to the pizza thing.

Definitely, they're
improving it. The core problem there is they
cannot make it work for every

single question you ask because
they lose a lot of link clicks, including simple things like
finding the sports score.

They're actually
putting Ticketmaster ads right now because they
need to make money. And their global
traffic on Search

is not actually
increasing anymore. So the only way to juice
more ad revenue out of Search

is to actually put
more ads per query. So answers, direct
answers, is completely

misaligned with
showing more link ads. It's very hard to make both
these products work together.

You need a new user interface,
new experience, new front end. And in the user's mind, they
don't want this clutter.
You get a knowledge panel. You get some ads. You get some links. You get some answer. You get some pictures.

It's too much clutter on Google. The thing that it
does incentivize, however, is for the people
who are putting the links up,

they have more of an incentive,
it's argued, that Google-- to produce high-quality,
trustworthy information,

there are some who
say Perplexity reduces those incentives because when
you reformat and summarize,

you provide less incentive for
those original content creators to actually put something
verifiable out there, the things

that you actually cite to. And so how do you
respond to that? Yeah. So the number one thing is that
we ensure that the sources are

right there at the top. For any query related to
news, we have a different UI

that we call as a trending UI,
where the news card-- the source cards are even more prominent,
that you can literally

click on them, and they're
very easy to click on. We're also having a
publisher program,

where we share revenue made on
a query with the publishers. And by the way, this is
something Google never did.

They make a lot of ad revenue. They tell publishers,
we're giving you traffic. But they don't share the ad
revenue with the publishers.

Instead, they make
the publishers put another ad
protocol, AdSense, which is putting ads all on the
sides and the pop-ups and things

like that, which is what really
frustrates the user from going to any site because they don't
want to see all this clutter.

They just came-- they
came to the landing page to read the news. And if publishers can run
that without putting ads

on their site, they would
get even more traffic. But Google doesn't
want that, right? So I think we are trying to
change the paradigm of even

how the business model works
here, where if we do put an ad, like a suggested
sponsored question,

and make a $1 on that
query, we're going to share. We're not going
to take all of it. We're going to share some of
that with the content providers

who were used as sources
for that question. And I think that's a
much more scalable way to incentivize publishers to
keep creating new content.

OK, cool. What do people get most
often wrong about Perplexity?

Well, there's this
whole thing of this, oh, this is just a wrapper. It's so easy to
build in a weekend.

You can always build like
an 80/20 or 70/30 version

of a Perplexity-like
clone in a weekend. That's due to two things.

One is there's a lot of
coding tools out there to write code faster. And two is, if we couldn't
have done it in a weekend,

we would not even be here. So it makes sense. But the thing that
people don't realize

is after doing
that first launch, we've done so much more work. We've worked on so many
different verticals.

We've built our own models. Today, if every model provider
stopped offering us models,

we can still run the product
with very little degradation in quality for most
of the questions that

are being answered today. And then we have been building
a big index of our own.

We're investing in our own
infrastructure to crawl the web. And then we're also having
all these modern research

agents that don't just quickly
pull the top links and summarize but actually do it
sequentially, like an agent,

and browsing the web
and looking at links and figuring out the next plan,
exposing the chain of thought.

So there's a lot of work we
put into the product that makes it so complicated.

Now the code base is so big
that if it is a wrapper, it's a really, really
valuable wrapper.

Yeah. Why shouldn't Apple acquire you? Well, it's more like, do
we want to sell to Apple?

That's the question to ask. If you were to put your mind
into Tim Cook's mind or Apple's

mind, do you think
this would be a-- I mean, if I were to tell
something to Tim Cook,

I would say, let Apple
Intelligence call Perplexity. We have our app
on the App Store.

On the Android OS,
we have an assistant that can call other apps,
and play songs and videos,

and set reminders, and send
emails, and make phone calls, and all of the stuff
already working.

So if Apple Intelligence opens
up developer access to more apps

and it can call
Perplexity, we would love to work together and
make Siri actually work.
OK, you heard it here first. OK. You are a bidder for TikTok.

Can you explain that? What is the logic behind
bidding for TikTok?

Yeah, so we wrote
this as our vision in a blog post on our website.

The core idea is that people
waste a lot of time on TikTok.

And I think the feed
can be more productive. I mean, that doesn't mean
taking away all the fun

and turning a party
into a library. But-- It could be a party still.

Like a more healthy mix of
useful content and making

sure misinformation can
be handled with things like community notes. We have an Ask
Perplexity bot on X

right now, which, despite
severe rate limits, has grown a lot in usage,
around 100 million impressions.

And it's very clear that the
sort of social usage of AIs

will increase. And AIs are even faster than
humans fact-checking things.

Like, essentially
because of Perplexity, fact-checking can be made
as a software service now.

You go to the web. You read all these things. You look at what
the user is saying or the video, whatever
the person is saying,

take the transcript
out of it, and add all the sources as
additional footnotes to give people more context.

used by the president or someone

It's called RAG,

And so it pulls the relevant

and puts it into the prompt,

We are compute

One is the next

So you probably don't

more power efficient also.

And the second thing
is distillation. There's this concept of a thing
I call distillation, where you can take a very
expensive model

and make it smaller by taking
its intelligence and cloning it, teaching a smaller model
to behave the same way

as the larger model. So that will reduce
the compute cost, too. So together with more compact
ships and smaller models,

I think we can slowly
bring down the power and compute requirements to
serve the same product today.

Discover Feed, which is our version of giving you

for a question, because
